previewPlan.name: MTB 100 mile - Event - High Volume - 2:1
previewPlan.description:
#### MTB 100 mile - Event - High Volume - 2:1


The first step in your journey to getting faster!

​

If you are in need of any technical help or want to know more about the training terms used in this plan check out the [Wahoo SYSTM Help Center.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenter)

​

Have a more specific question that isn't addressed in the Help Center? Head over to our [forum](https://wahoox.forum.wahoofitness.com/) to see if your question has been answered, or just post it for yourself.

​

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Revolver Is Easy (Mash-Up)
prospects.description:
Why limit yourself to one type of interval duration, intensity, and recovery time when you can add two of the best Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) and Anaerobic Capacity (AC) sessions in the SUF library together? Better yet, why not add them together in a way that makes the session as challenging as possible?

​

The first 11 intervals from _Revolver_ ensure that your AC system has been repeatedly tapped so many times that your cardiovascular system is having to work overtime to compensate. Then just before you really reach the limit of your AC’s ability to recover, we serve up shorter, higher intensity intervals with equally short recovery times. Those shorter efforts push your AC all the way to the edge and then over it. At this point, your cardiovascular system is left to take up the slack, forcing your body into new depths of anaerobic depletion. By the end of this workout, you will have pushed your AC and MAP to their breaking point. Your reward? The ability to hit them even harder the next time you need to put down multiple attacks or surges.

prospects.name: The Soul of a Cyclist
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Directed by Nuno Tavares, The Soul of a Cyclist revolves around the subject of classic bicycles**. **Shot in Portugal and in England, the film captures personal experiences of individuals who own and ride classic bicycles and their deep connection with them. A film full of curiosity, joy and adventure.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Bavaria: Burgberg
prospects.description:
This may be a short workout, but it packs a serious punch—so lace up those gloves and get ready for 22 powerful 10-second seated sprints!

After a gentle warm-up leaving the picturesque village of Sulzberg, we’ll dive straight into our first block: 8 x 10-second high-cadence seated sprints with 50 seconds of recovery.

As the road naturally levels out, we’ll catch our breath before hitting the core of the workout—9 x 10-second low-cadence seated sprints with the same 50-second recovery, focusing on maintaining rock-solid form.

To close things out, we’ll return to the high-cadence style for a final round of 5 x 10-second sprints. This session is designed to sharpen muscle activation and improve recovery after intense efforts.

Finish strong, and I’ll see you in Burgberg!

​

With short near-maximal sprint efforts like these, you’ll recruit all of the muscle fibers in your legs. While cadence builds force your muscles to contract and relax as quickly as possible, this session forces your muscles to contract with maximal power. Just like cadence builds, this session becomes one of the best ways to train your neuromuscular system.

Even if your target event does not require you to complete maximal sprints, there is a substantial trickle-down efficiency effect to the longer-duration power efforts when you train your neuromuscular system.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9866624296)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Sub-Threshold With Surges: 4 x 8
prospects.description:
While some of you will know this intensity level as "Sweet-Spot", we prefer the name Sub-Threshold, because we want to drive home the fact that you should keep your power below FTP. In the same way that longer Tempo efforts can feel "easy," these shorter Sub-Threshold efforts can also feel "easy". After all, if you can hold 100% of FTP for about an hour, then holding less than that for 8 minutes should be a piece of cake right? We know you can go harder for this short amount of time, but that is not what we are asking for.

​

This session is not intended to push you to your limits, nor is it designed to be a massive training load. The real purpose is to essentially keep your fatigue levels right where they are, by giving your body just enough intensity to ensure that you are not "more recovered" after today.

​

While some folks will say that there is no training benefit to such short Sub-Threshold efforts, when viewed in a bigger picture sense (like a 3-week training block) they can be the perfect efforts to ensure you get the most out of a longer training block.

​

We would even ask that you view this session as more of an assessment, rather than strictly a workout. That's because you should be comparing this power output to heart rate response and your own internal RPE. When you have heavy fatigue, your heart rate will struggle to hit its normal peaks. When fresh you would be getting into Z4 heart rate by the end of the last two intervals, and your RPE should never really climb above a 7. When holding onto excess fatigue, your heart rate won't climb above Z3, and your RPE will be above an 8. At the same time, if you have gained a significant amount of fitness, your Heart Rate will stay in Z3, and your RPE won't climb above 6. The secondary tell between improved fitness and fatigue is how quickly your heart rate drops after each effort. When fatigued, your heart rate won't drop below Z2 during the recovery.

​

While it is easy to rely solely on Power, you should always refer back to RPE and Heart Rate, and today is the perfect session to practice comparing the 3.

​

​

**Warm-Up**

20 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%

1 minute @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <85%

1 minute @ RPE 6 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <90%

30 seconds @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <95%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 90-95% of AC (130-180% of FTP)

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 4

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

Interval Repeats per Set: 4

**Interval**

Surge: 30 sec @ RPE 8.5 -- 90% of MAP (105-130% of FTP)

Steady: 1 minutes 30 seconds @ RPE 7 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <100%

​

**Extra Volume**

13 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <85%

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- <45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Endurance  3
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right!

​

Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles." Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm and your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

Warm-Up

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

Main Effort

Number of Sets

8.5

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set

1

Interval: 10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

Extra Volume

N/A

​

Cool Down

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: The Omnium
prospects.description:
Do you know what we love about you? Your versatility. You can Suffer anywhere, anytime, and in any way. That's why Grunter von Agony, Sufferlandrian Team Director, is sending you to compete in The Omnium at the UCI World Track Championships. Over the course of 50 minutes, you'll do battle in the six different races.

​

No two intervals in this workout are the same, with each one working slightly different Neuromuscular (NM), Anaerobic Capacity (AC), and Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) variations. No need for FTP here, friends. It's the perfect session to improve top-end power without having to do a ton of repetitive efforts.

​

The Scratch Race and Flying Lap have an easy enough lead-in that you get to put your max sprint to the full test. Add in the standing starts for the Individual Pursuit and Kilo, and you give your NM a real run-through. The repeated surges of the Elimination Race, the all-out nature of the Kilo, and the massive efforts you have to make in the points race really test your powers of recovery while working your AC all the way to the max.

​

Since the efforts come in quick succession, and with most being over four minutes in length, your cardiovascular system never catches a real break, ensuring your MAP doesn’t get left out of the equation.

prospects.name: Four Shorts by Joey
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2021): Joey Schusler travels the world on his bike making films and having a wonderful time so you don't have to. Or something like that. This collection of short films highlights some of Joey's most interesting adventures, from riding the streets of Kathmandu with Nepal's most talented mountain biker to crashing in remote mountain valleys, you'll be planning your own epic trips before you've even finished the workout.

​

🚴 Workout: While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, riding to this Inspiration film is a great way to watch an interesting film while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: French Pyrenees: Lac de Cap de Long
prospects.description:
Set in the heart of the Hautes-Pyrénées, this ride starts at Saint-Lary-Soulon and explores the sensational Route de Lac, finishing at the 2,160m summit of Lac de Cap de Long. The 22km climb is long, so we break it up into three sections for you. First, you'll have a nice long warm-up to ride into the village of Fabian. Once the proper climb starts, you'll ramp it up to a range between 70-90% threshold and hold it there. Toward the end, you'll start to work hard and finish off with an all-out assault on the summit. Along the way, you'll find out how the local wool is processed, how a network of ancient towers protected the region, why one house is covered in flowers, and what happened to all the local brown bears.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/3778259865)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Sub-Threshold With Surges: 4 x 12
prospects.description:
Yep, there are good chunks of sub-threshold in here. But what makes this session special are the surges above threshold during each effort. Your body's ability to clear metabolites and process oxygen doesn't really change at 90% of FTP and above. What that means it that whether you are at 90% or 100% of FTP your body is clearing those things out at the same rate. It's just that at FTP your body is producing more of those metabolites that it is capable of clearing.

​

By surging above FTP you are creating metabolites faster than your body can clear them. If you were to settle into 100% of FTP, you would only be clearing things out at the rate you are producing them. That means whatever you have produced from that surge will just stay there. By dropping just below FTP your body is clearing things out faster than you are producing them. That means that the excess you got from that surge will slowly be cleared out.

​

Each time a surge pops up during this workout, your body should have just about cleared what was made from the last surge. Not only does this push your body's ability to clear these things to the max, but it also teaches your mind to deal with the discomfort of burning lungs and legs associated with these efforts at or above threshold.

​

A simpler way to think of this is that you are teaching your body and mind to "recover" just below FTP. Not only does this help bump up your FTP, but it also helps you recover that much faster anytime you let off the gas, whether for a downhill, turn, or finding a good draft. Having the confidence that you can recover while feeling so uncomfortable can mean the difference between hanging onto to a new personal best and completely throwing in the towel.

​

This is the perfect session to practice your positive thinking from the Mental Toughness Program (If you haven't checked that out already you definitely should!).

​

**Warm Up**

20 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

1 minute @ RPE 5.5 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <90%

30 seconds @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 90-95% of AC (130-180% of FTP)

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 4

Rest between sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval repeats per set: 4

**Interval**

Work: 30 seconds @ RPE 8.5 -- 120% of FTP -- HR >105%

Steady: 2 minutes 30 seconds @ RPE 6.5 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <100%

​

**Extra Volume**

25 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Cool Down**

7 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: Trails: Cruising 3.5
prospects.description:
**What?** 

A trail ride at a cruisy pace.

​

**Why?** 

Variety is the spice of life and it’s also the best way to accomplish a few goals simultaneously. Focus on targeting your weaknesses during this trail session in order to improve them come race day.

​

**How?** 

This is an unstructured ride - let the trail do the thinking today. If you find a section that you struggle to hit cleanly, repeat that section a few times until you feel comfortable with it. Don’t feel the need to practice every section you struggle with on a single ride, you can always come back another day! Keep the effort below 85% of FTP at all times and spend the bulk of the ride around 60% of FTP.

​

Make sure to warm up well and cool down afterwards.

prospects.name: Adventure For All 2023
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023): As one of Wahoo's close partners, Adventure For All's mission is to guide individuals with exceptionalities through life-changing adventures while creating innovative educational practices that ignite a shift in societal belief systems.Together we will guide individuals with exceptionalities through life-changing adventures while creating innovative educational practices that ignite a shift in societal belief systems.

​

**Experience the Adirondacks:**

Join four exceptional athletes in the Adirondack mountains on the adventure of a lifetime. These athletes challenge themselves, conquer fears, and demonstrate their ability to overcome obstacles, proving to themselves and the world they can achieve anything.

​

**Finish:**

Witness Riley, a remarkable young man with Autism and Tourette's, as he pedals beyond expectations to conquer the challenging 31+ mile Big Sugar gravel bike race. This isn't just a story about cycling; it's a journey of courage, hope, and the shattering barriers. With the unwavering support of his mom and the dedicated team at Adventure For All, Riley's adventure redefines what's possible, turning every pedal stroke into a victory for him and everyone who believed in his endless potential.

​

[**Find out more about Adventure For All**](https://adventureforall.org/)

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: London-Edinburgh-London
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2016): London Edinburgh London follows a group of cyclists from around the world on a remarkable feat of endurance. Join their ride up the length of Britain - from London to Edinburgh and back again - in under five days. Traveling over 1400km, a continuous distance far further than most of them had ever ridden before, our unlikely and eccentric heroes are not only tested physically but face the mental challenge, "can I push myself further? Can I go one more day?".

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Tempo High Cadence: 4 x 3
prospects.description:
The training benefit of this session comes down to the uncomfortably high cadence you need to hold during each effort. Even though these efforts are under FTP, the high leg speed required will leave your system working harder than usual for the required power output.

By maintaining the highest cadence possible (without bouncing in the saddle) you end up pushing your neuromuscular coordination near its limits in a similar way to Cadence Builds.

​

With an emphasis on low torque (high RPM) efforts this session is polar opposite to sessions like GOAT and Power Station. Even though these efforts are short and below FTP the high cadence places more of a load on your cardiovascular system, so expect your heart rate and breathing to be higher than normal for the power.

​

Since muscles can only contract (pull) any given muscle will primarily move a joint in a single direction. When it comes to pedaling a bike, your quads and glutes can push the pedals down, while your hamstrings and hip flexors pull the pedals back up (with the help of your glutes and quads on the other leg). If you were to pedal with one leg (as you do in Cadence Drills) and your hamstrings and glutes were unable to contract, once you get to the bottom of the pedal stroke your leg would be stuck down there. No matter how hard you might try, your glutes and quads will do nothing to help you get that pedal all the way around. Suppose you do have both feet clipped in, and you are letting your opposite leg push down to bring your leg back up to 12 o'clock. If your quads and glutes are still contracting (pushing the pedal down) while the glutes and quads of your other leg are starting to push their pedal down, you will end up with one leg working against the other. You must relax the glutes and quads of one leg to get all of the power out of the glutes and quads of your other leg.

This is where neuromuscular coordination comes into play. During each pedal revolution, your legs have to “switch on” and “switch off” almost all of the muscles in your legs. By maintaining your highest cadence without bouncing, you are pushing all of the muscles in each leg to contract and relax (switch on and off) as quickly as possible.

While we give specific cadence targets in this session, everyone has a different limit to what cadence they can maintain before bouncing in the saddle. To get the intended benefit of this session you need to maintain the power targets at the highest cadence that YOU can maintain. For some that might be 105RPM, for others, it might be 150RPM. What matters is that you push YOUR neuromuscular system to its limits.

​

**Warm Up**

15 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 3

Rest between sets: 7 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval repeats per: NA

**Interval**

3 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 80% of FTP -- 100+ RPM -- HR <95%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.description:

prospects.name: 14 Vise Grips
prospects.description:
You can never have too many tools in the shed. After years of lobbying, we finally convinced Grunter von Agony to share his favorite set of implements with us: the fabled _14 Vise Grips_. Taken individually, each of the 14 intervals might appear tame, incapable of inflicting a significant squeeze. But when expertly applied in the correct order, they apply just the right kind of pressure to turn a Couchlandrian into a Sufferlandrian, just like turning coal into diamonds.

​

While the duration of each Vise Grip varies (from 30 seconds to 2 minutes), the power targets and recovery durations between them remain constant. The first 30-second interval should feel like a Sunday stroll in the park, but by the end of the first 2-minute Vise Grip, you'll be cursing Grunter's name. As the intervals get shorter, time will appear to stretch. That final 30-second effort will feel like an eternity. When you roll up to the second set, you'll know what you're in for, so just put your head down and prepare yourself to crush or be crushed.

​

Once you make it through all 14 Vise Grips, you will have been north of your Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) for a total of 16 minutes. Changing the duration of the efforts (while keeping the same recovery) stresses your Anaerobic Capacity (AC) in a more dynamic way than, say, a more straightforward on/off session like _Half is Easy_. Since the longer efforts have the same recovery duration as the shorter ones, you will eventually deplete your AC, forcing your body to rely on your MAP to hit the required power targets. As the intervals get shorter in the second half of each set, you'll find that you have just enough left in the tank to complete the next effort.

​

Ultimately this workout combines the advantages of shorter, higher-power intervals with longer recovery (great for building muscular strength) with the advantages of longer, higher-power intervals with inadequate recovery (great for driving up your MAP and improving your AC).

prospects.name: From the Ground Up - Season 3 Pt 4
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023):

**Episode 6: Hours : Minutes : Seconds**

The final episode of Season 3, five separate stories that you have watched grow over the last 5 months, culminating in Leadville for the race. What is often missed in this project is that we truly believe in building a team, a family and more, that it would be even tougher to do alone. Sit down on your couch with some popcorn and a blanket, but don't forget to bring your friends - this one is full of moments that will make you want to get off the couch!

​

🚴 Workout: the workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts aren't the hardest you'll experience so that you can keep your attention on the film, however, they are just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts. The workout intensity reflects the intensity of the riders in many places, so you may feel as if you're climbing Mont Ventoux or that you're a part of a sprint lead-out train on the run into the finish line.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Do As You're Told
prospects.description:
The little voice in your head is telling you to stop. The screams from your legs are nearly deafening. But you hear none of it. You're following orders to ATTACK.

​

This is the story of two men in a car—your team directors—who guide you to GLORY. Ignore them at your own risk: They will not tolerate insubordination.

​

In this session, you'll tackle two sets of 11 intervals each. The first set has high-intensity efforts with matching recoveries. This pushes your body's ability to recover right to the limit -- just what you need to improve Anaerobic Capacity (AC). The shorter, super-high intensity efforts also help with your Neuromuscular Power (NM). The second set features inverse intervals with opposite efforts and recoveries. This really depletes your body's AC, so you need to rely on your aerobic system. This helps develop your Maximal Aerobic Power.

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Sprints: 12 x 10s
prospects.description:
This is a session that you'll want to complete in Level, rather than Erg, mode. The only time we would suggest Erg mode is if you are unable to maintain the lower power targets set between sprints.

With short maximal sprint efforts, you'll recruit every muscle fiber you have in your legs with each effort. While cadence builds force your muscles to contract and relax as quickly as possible, this session forces your muscles to contract with maximal force. Just like cadence builds this session becomes one of the best ways to train your neuromuscular system. Even if your target event does not require you to complete maximal sprints, there is a substantial trickle-down effect to the longer duration power efforts when you train your neuromuscular system.

This session is a great alternate to cadence builds or standing starts for those completing our SUF Strength sessions. On days you complete off the bike strength work you want your on bike training to complement the suffering you put yourself through off the bike. That means short maximal efforts (whether for power or for cadence) are the best workouts to complement the strength gains you've made off the bike.

As long as you run this session in slope mode you can complete the sprints either seated or out of the saddle. For those competing in events that do not require much (if any) standing (such as Time Trials or Triathlons) you should complete these sprints seated (and in the aerobars or drops if that is where you are racing).

You should also do these efforts seated if you don't feel an out-of-the-saddle maximal sprint is stable/safe to do on your trainer. Regardless of using ERG or Slope mode, you do not want to hold anything back on any sprint. Seeing your peak power drop as the session goes on is totally normal as your legs fatigue. This is where RPE really becomes the most important metric, rather than power, heart rate, or cadence.

Now get on that bike and CRUSH IT!

​

**Warm Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 12

Rest between sets: 9 minutes 50 seconds @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval repeats per set: NA

**Interval**

10 seconds @ RPE 10 -- 200% of FTP -- >105%

**Extra Volume**

N/A

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: A Very Dark Place
prospects.description: You know that ride where you thought you went harder, deeper, and to a darker place than you'd ever gone before? HAHAHAHA. This takes you further, deeper, and darker than that. _A Very Dark Place_ (AVDP) is about maximum effort for shorter durations: five, four-minute intervals that take you to the limit. If you struggle with longer, high-intensity efforts and want to improve your ability to make repeated attacks, you need to spend some time in _A Very Dark Place_. Those little punches in the third and fifth efforts will teach you just how dark it can get.

prospects.name: Made This
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2024): In professional bike racing, we don't often see the whole picture. We only see the starts and the finishes, the breakaways and crashes, the near misses and podiums. Made This presented by Wahoo + MAAP is a series of behind-the-scenes, unfiltered front-row access with women's pro cycling team Lifeplus - Wahoo:

1. **Sisterhood: **Dedication, challenges, commitment, belief, family and sisterhood are all components of what it takes to be a professional racing team. In the first of a series of behind-the-scenes, unfiltered front-row access with team Lifeplus-Wahoo, MADE THIS is a collection of short films from MAAP Pro Team Racing that reveals what it takes to make a champion a champion.
2. **Prepared for anything: **The excitement of Holy Week at the Tour de Flanders is upon us, and Team Lifeplus-Wahoo is gearing up for a challenging ride. With 163km to conquer, featuring 12 climbs and seven cobbled stretches, not to mention seven slippery flat stone sections—all under a deluge of rain—anything could happen.
3. **Passion on the cobbles: **Join us as we dive deep into the chaotic and exhilarating world of the Paris-Roubaix, one of cycling's most grueling races. Amidst the cobblestones and mud, Team Lifeplus-Wahoo faces the ultimate test of endurance and skill. With a new lineup and high stakes, the team navigates the unpredictable nature of this legendary race, where luck can play a huge role and every second counts.
4. **Home sweet home: **After a fallow year for the tour, the team are eager to push for results in front of an expectant crowd. But instead of the warm welcome on familiar roads, disaster strikes the first morning of the race. As national news of the unfortunate event breaks, the team are left wondering if they'll be able to compete or if this becomes a home visit to forget. What follows is a true act of human kindness and a gesture that symbolises the unifying bond of the women's pro peloton.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: To Get To The Other Side
prospects.description:
While you might think the only way to improve your FTP is to ride at, or above, your existing FTP, that isn't always the case. Your body can only handle so much time above FTP in any given week (or month, for that matter). But that doesn’t mean you should sit around doing nothing the rest of the time.

​

Your body is most efficient at clearing out lactate and other metabolic byproducts at 80-95% of FTP. This is one of the few sessions where you can consistently sit at that intensity and let your body churn away at this nice, efficient effort level. It's the ideal workout to end a hard, three-day block or add in during a rest week. It will give your body a little training stimulus while still allowing it to recover from whatever tortures you've recently put it through.

prospects.name: FTP/MAP Builds: 2 Sets 4 x 4
prospects.description:
This brutal but straightforward workout is perfect for developing both FTP and MAP while teaching you a Negative Split pacing strategy. For this workout, you will complete a series of 4-minute efforts. The first 3-minutes are right at your FTP, which isn't so tough in itself, but the final 1-minute of each effort are set above 90% of MAP.

​

When we talk about a "negative split" we mean completing the second half of an effort at a higher speed/power than the first half. By the time you hit the MAP portion of each interval, your heart rate and breathing rate will already be nice and high. This limits the AC demand of a standalone MAP effort, where you have a large lag time between producing the power requirement, and your body delivering the oxygen needed to hold that power. Usually, that lag time between oxygen demand and oxygen supply is covered by your AC. Paced correctly, your heart rate should essentially be increasing for the entire 4-minutes, as it will be settling into LTHR right as you up the power output.

​

As you complete each effort, holding 100% of FTP will feel harder and harder. This in itself is excellent mental practice for "feeling" how your RPE for the same power can drift up as fatigue sets in. Knowing what 100% of FTP feels like when your legs are nearly spent is a great reminder of why starting an effort too hard will bite you in the end.

​

This workout ends up delivering a fantastic aerobic workload as you complete 8-minutes of MAP work with minimal help from your AC, making this an excellent session for those who have a strong AC but weak MAP. You also rack up 24-minutes at 100% of FTP, which by itself would be a good training load. Add in these MAP efforts, and you multiply the training impact of those 24-minutes.

​

Regardless of your chosen discipline or event, this is a session that will benefit everyone, both regarding learning good pacing and giving your aerobic system a big training boost.

​

**Warm-Up**

20 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <85%

1 minute @ RPE 6 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <90%

30 seconds @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <95%

30 seconds @ RPE 8 -- 90% of MAP (105-135% of FTP)

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 2

Rest Between Sets: 15 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set: 4

**Interval**

FTP Effort: 3 minutes @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

VO2 Effort: 1 minute @ RPE 9 -- 90-95% of MAP (105-130% of FTP) 

Recovery: 5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70% 

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

4 minutes @ RPE 1 -- <45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Trails: Cruising 4
prospects.description:
**What?** 

A trail ride at a cruisy pace.

​

**Why?** 

Variety is the spice of life and it’s also the best way to accomplish a few goals simultaneously. Focus on targeting your weaknesses during this trail session in order to improve them come race day.

​

**How?** 

This is an unstructured ride - let the trail do the thinking today. If you find a section that you struggle to hit cleanly, repeat that section a few times until you feel comfortable with it. Don’t feel the need to practice every section you struggle with on a single ride, you can always come back another day! Keep the effort below 85% of FTP at all times and spend the bulk of the ride around 60% of FTP.

​

Make sure to warm up well and cool down afterwards.

prospects.name: Wahoo Frontiers 2023
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023): Discover the incredible stories behind some of this year's top Wahooligan athletes:

**Chelsea Sodaro** is the reigning IRONMAN World Champion, but beyond her athletic prowess, Chelsea's greatest source of pride is her ability to show up for herself and her daughter. Chelsea shares the power of finding her voice, advocating for female athletes, and why motherhood is her most significant victory to date. Follow Chelsea's journey to defending her World Champion title in 2023.

​

**Heather Jackson:** As one chapter closes, a new one opens. After 15 years as a professional triathlete, Heather Jackson decided to challenge herself in new ways, build a fresh community, and push her own and other's expectations of what is humanly possible. In June, Heather tackled the Unbound Gravel 200, often hailed as the "Super Bowl" of gravel bike racing, and the iconic Western States Endurance Run, the world’s oldest 100-mile trail race. Facing these demanding events with just a two-week gap between them, the question looms: how will Heather approach her most ambitious goal yet?

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Serbia Upside Down Ep. 2
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Serbia. A small country in the Balkan Peninsula that hides some of the most beautiful natural wonders and unique cultural heritage in this part of the world. Yet it remains unknown to many. Only the alternative, curious and brave plan their journeys in this hidden gem. However, a small self-organized crew from Serbia and Germany set a mission to discover and reveal those stunning natural creations of Serbia. On a bicycle. In just five days, they traversed 450 kilometers across six mountains of Western Serbia, and climbed around 11,000 meters to film and produce what you are about to experience.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Half Monty (Ramp Test)
prospects.description:
**Half Monty: The Easy One.**

​

We recommend this fitness test for:

- Newer riders
- Athletes with limited experience pacing maximal efforts / fitness testing.
- Those who are mid-plan or who just want to get a sense of where their fitness is.

The _Half Monty_ 4DP fitness test is the most accurate and complete ramp test available. While it's not as comprehensive or as accurate as our main fitness test, _Full Frontal_, it's far more approachable and easier to pace for new riders. It also doesn't require any special preparation. You just need to feel relatively fresh.

​

Based on more than a year of research (and after dozens of lab tests and thousands of online tests) and using sophisticated analysis of power and heart rate data, _Half Monty_ is far more accurate and comprehensive than standard ramp tests.

​

It also tells you more about who you are as an athlete. _Half Monty_ provides you with your FTP, Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and Cycling Threshold Heart Rate (cTHR), all of which we use to personalize your workout targets.

​

If you're still using the 4DP estimates when you set up your account, _Half Monty_ will also refine your AC and NM estimates (but will not do so if you've done _Full Frontal_ or manually adjusted your estimates). If you want fully accurate AC and NM, as well as your Rider Type, Strengths, Weaknesses, and training plans adjusted to those Strengths and Weaknesses, you'll need to expose yourself to the _Full Frontal_ 4DP fitness test.

​

Ready to climb the ramp? You'll need the following before you start:

- A heart rate monitor if you want the most accurate results. Don't have one? Order one [HERE](https://wahoofitness.com/devices)
- Some kind of power device connected (trainer, power meter, virtual power, etc.)
- Be ready to pay close attention to the instructions in the workout
- Be sure your profile is complete and up-to-date (Profile > About You). Accurate information helps us make our calculations

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[Why Fitness Testing Matters](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/testing-testing-1-2-3-why-fitness-testing-matters)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

​

[Here's some more information on how to get the most from your fitness test.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterFitnessAssessment)

prospects.name: Endurance  1
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

​

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high and your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week. Shorter Endurance rides (like this one) can fit in both a hard week of training and a recovery week. That is, only if you do it right! Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles."

​

Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride, especially one under 90 minutes should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted.

So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like? For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70%, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in low to mid Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can; for most this is 80-90rpm. Also, your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster, but you will have to trust us on this one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions, or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats Per Set: 2

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

**Extra Volume**

NA

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: The Chores
prospects.description:
If you want a do-it-all session that will maintain and improve nearly every aspect of your fitness, _The Chores_ is just the ticket. This workout features 3 sets of intervals. Each set combines a series of 40-second efforts with 20-second recoveries, followed by an immediate transition to a sustained effort just below threshold. These short efforts with minimal recovery deplete your anaerobic gas tank, forcing your body to get better at producing power aerobically. This combination will help improve your Anaerobic Capacity, (AC) your Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and your Functional Threshold Power (FTP), all in just under an hour.

​

At the start of each set, your body starts to dip into your anaerobic reserves to help hit the high-power targets. Your body then starts to ramp up your oxygen intake in order to produce more of the power requirements aerobically. With such short recovery time between these efforts, your AC is steadily drained through each set. By the time the last short interval arrives, your body will be forced to produce almost all of that power aerobically, which will push your lungs to their very limit.

​

This is the optimal time to stress your body’s ability to produce power at threshold. With your AC depleted (and your lungs and heart working near maximal capacity), the shorter sustained efforts that would normally be a piece of cake will have a bit more...sting. No matter what your preferred discipline, terrain, or distance, this session will make you fitter and faster.

​

Featuring exciting, on-bike camera footage from the Velon Hammer Series, _The Chores_ will make you earn your keep.

prospects.name: Chasing the Sun
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023): Fresh from a sold-out tour of UK cinemas, Chasing The Sun is the new documentary film from 2x BAFTA-winning director Michael B.Clifford. It explores extraordinary personal stories of ordinary cyclists taking on iconic endurance event Chase The Sun, revealing the power of the humble bicycle to transform lives and help save the planet.

The film features contributions from broadcaster and ITV’s voice of the Tour de France Ned Boulting, author and blogger Jools Walker, Turner Prize-winning artist Sir Richard Long and 4x Mountain Bike World Champion Tracy Moseley.

​

🚴 Workout: the workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts aren't the hardest you'll experience so that you can keep your attention on the film, however, they are just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts. The workout intensity reflects the intensity of the riders in many places, so you may feel as if you're climbing Mont Ventoux or that you're a part of Cav's lead-out train on the run into the finish line.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Clobber
prospects.description:
The 3x25-minute sub-threshold workout is one of the most classic interval sessions out there, so prepare for a trip to the northern Painlands for this FTP-builder. The reason the 3x25 sub-threshold workout is so popular is that it is easy to follow, helps teach good pacing, and gives you a great threshold training stimulus.

​

In this case, you're looking at three, (roughly) 25-minute blocks at around 90% of your FTP, an effort we refer to as "Sub-Threshold". Many refer to this intensity as "Sweet-Spot", but we prefer Sub-Threshold, as the real key is to never let your power creep above your FTP. Staying just below threshold ensures that your effort remains at an intensity you know your body can handle but that is close to what would not be sustainable.

​

The only way you're going to make it through three of these efforts is if you pace yourself properly. Everyone feels just fine for the first 5 minutes of the first effort, and are often tempted to go harder. Don't be that person. More often than not, that person blows up spectacularly in the second interval, unable to finish the session. Or they have to ride that second interval at lower power, turning it into a Tempo session, which is not the goal.

​

Getting a sense of how these efforts "bite" towards the end is vital to learning how to pace yourself over longer steady-state efforts; whether that's a time trial, local climb, breakaway, triathlon, or even a good old fitness test. In each of those cases, the pacing is key. Learning how your perceived effort can steadily climb even though your power remains unchanged is critical to good pacing.

​

So how do you know if you are doing this one right? As we said, the first 5 minutes should feel relatively easy. Around that 5-minute mark, your heart rate should stop climbing, and settle into 2-5% below your Lactate Threshold Heart Rate (LTHR). If your heart rate is climbing for the entire effort and goes above your LTHR, then you are going too hard.

If you hit the 10-minute mark, your legs feel fine, and your heart rate is still in Zone 3, then you aren't going hard enough.

If you've never done a session like this before, you can consider only doing the first 20-minute effort, or even sticking to just the first 15 minutes of each effort. There's no shame in building up to this full session, so don't be afraid to pause and fast forward as needed.

​

Nailing this session is really about getting in tune with your body and understanding what the edge between a sustainable and an unsustainable effort feels like. Not being able to complete this workout is fairly common, so don't beat yourself up if you can't make it through the first few times. As long as you come away from this session with a better understanding of how to pace longer efforts, you've improved as an athlete.

prospects.name: Sprints: 3 Sets 8 x 10s Decreasing Recovery
prospects.description:
**Smart trainer users: This workout is best done in level mode!**

If you're a sprinter, or someone with an anaerobic capacity strength, you're going to love this workout. If not, well, you might hate it. BUT the good news is that each effort only lasts 10 seconds, so the discomfort isn't nearly what you get in The Trick or the other AC focused NoVids. prospects.name: Endurance 4.5
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles."

So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70%, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.)

Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm

Also, your RPE should be a 2-3

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm-Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set: 13

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <85%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: The Model
prospects.description:
They say that beauty is in the eye of the beholder. And through the bleeding eyes of Sufferlandrians, what could possibly be more beautiful than the sharp, saw-tooth profile of the workout you see before you? Full of gorgeous, shapely, shimmering blocks of yellow Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) efforts interspersed with mercifully brief and slightly inadequate recoveries, it's a real stunner.

​

But you know what's even better looking than this alluring workout? You (after you've completed the workout, that is). Originally designed by our Head of Sports Science, Neal Henderson, for his professional athletes, The Model is a beautiful portrait of MAP brutality. It's one of those sessions that you think you can't finish, but always somehow do. It will leave you breathless, feeling all tingly, a bit confused and lying in a blubbering heap. It's a look. It will also deliver a nice boost to your fitness that always looks and feels good.

​

A true love letter to the beauty of professional cycling, The Model features a banging soundtrack and thrilling footage from both the men's and women's pelotons. With its eclectic design, effects, and graphics, you'll find yourself unable to tear your eyes away from the action on screen (assuming you can lift them from your stem).

prospects.name: The Last Rider
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2022): The heroic true story of American cyclist Greg LeMond, considered to be one of the greatest cyclists of all time, who defied the odds for one of the most triumphant comeback stories in sporting history. The first, male American to win the Tour de France, LeMond came back from the brink of death to beat his famed rivals in the historic and nail-biting race at the 1989 Tour de France.

Directed by Alex Holmes and featuring exclusive interviews with LeMond and his wife Kathy as well as, never before seen footage, The Last Rider is an exhilarating portrait of one of the greatest athletes of our time.

​

🚴 Workout: the workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts aren't the hardest you'll experience so that you can keep your attention on the film, however, they are just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts. The workout intensity reflects the intensity of the riders in many places, so you may feel as if you're climbing Mont Ventoux or that you're a part of Cav's lead-out train on the run into the finish line.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Big Gear MAP: 2 Sets 6 x 30s
prospects.description:
This session is focused on building MAP power at low cadences, which improves muscular endurance. This session includes 2 sets of 6 X 30s intervals at 100% of MAP power with 90s of progressive recovery, building from 50 to 60% of FTP with increasing cadence every 30s.

​

While the efforts have a MAP target, your heart rate will not likely go over Zone 4 due to the short duration of the efforts and even more-so because of the low cadence targets.

​

prospects.name: The Other French Race
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Rupert Guinness entered the Haute Route Alps in France looking for a new challenge to test his physical and mental strength. But after 800km of cycling through the Alps from Nice to Megève, the cycling journalist and author realized that the experience had delivered to him and the 400-plus starters something far greater. It had provided them with the adventure of a lifetime; from a sense of what it would be like to ride in the fabled Tour de France that he has reported on more than 30 times, to the creation of friendships with fellow riders forged by their shared suffering and encouragement for one another as they cycled through some of the toughest and most spectacular mountains that cycling has to offer.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: FTP/MAP Builds: 2 Sets 3 x 6
prospects.description:
This brutal but straightforward workout is perfect for developing both FTP and MAP while teaching you a Negative Split pacing strategy. For this workout, you will complete a series of 6-minute efforts. The first 4-minutes are right at your FTP, which isn't so tough in itself, but the final 2-minutes of each effort are set above 90% of MAP.

​

When we talk about a "negative split" we mean completing the second half of an effort at a higher speed/power than the first half. By the time you hit the MAP portion of each interval, your heart rate and breathing rate will already be nice and high. This limits the AC demand of a standalone MAP effort, where you have a large lag time between producing the power requirement, and your body delivering the oxygen needed to hold that power. Usually, that lag time between oxygen demand and oxygen supply is covered by your AC. Paced correctly, your heart rate should essentially be increasing for the entire 6-minutes, as it will be settling into LTHR right as you up the power output.

​

As you complete each effort, holding 100% of FTP will feel harder and harder. This in itself is excellent mental practice for "feeling" how your RPE for the same power can drift up as fatigue sets in. Knowing what 100% of FTP feels like when your legs are nearly spent is a great reminder of why starting an effort too hard will bite you in the end.

​

This workout ends up delivering a fantastic aerobic workload as you complete 12-minutes of MAP work with minimal help from your AC. Making this an excellent session for those who have a strong AC, but weak MAP. You also rack up 24-minutes at 100% of FTP, which by itself would be a good training load. Add in these MAP efforts, and you multiply the training impact of those 24-minutes.

​

Regardless of your chosen discipline or event, this is a session that will benefit everyone, both regarding learning good pacing and giving your aerobic system a big training boost.

​

**Warm Up**

20 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

Rest between sets: 30 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

**Interval**

Effort 1: 4 minutes @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

Effort 2: 2 minutes @ RPE 8.5 -- 120% of FTP -- HR >105%

Rest: 5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Extra Volume**

​

**Cool Down**

prospects.name: Endurance 5
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right!

Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles." Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm and your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm-Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 14

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set: 1

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: The Amazing Chase
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2021): Ultra-endurance cyclist Jack Thompson set out to ride the 2021 Tour de France route as fast as he could. 3,552km divided over 21 stages, his goal was to chase down the PRO peloton on his way to Paris. What would it take? What was realistic? What was possible? Follow Jack's journey as he battles the elements, the vagaries of the route, and intense mental and physical fatigue to arrive at the Champs-Élysées in Paris.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session, which is a very low-intensity ride. It's so easy that your power remains at or below 50% of FTP or an RPE less than 2.5, and your heart rate stays in zone 1 the entire time. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting (But not so interesting that you can't pay attention to the film).

prospects.name: Fairless
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2015): This is the story of Australian cycling legend Steve Fairless who at only twenty-six years old rode for Australia in the 1988 Seoul Olympics before giving up his sport to raise a family. Now at fifty, Steve’s finally ready to make a comeback, proving it’s never too late to chase your dreams.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Trails: Cruising 1.5
prospects.description:
**What?**

A trail ride at a cruisy pace.

​

**Why?**

Variety is the spice of life and it’s also the best way to accomplish a few goals simultaneously. Focus on targeting your weaknesses during this trail session in order to improve them come race day.

​

**How?**

This is an unstructured ride - let the trail do the thinking today. If you find a section that you struggle to hit cleanly, repeat that section a few times until you feel comfortable with it. Don’t feel the need to practice every section you struggle with on a single ride, you can always come back another day! Keep the effort below 85% of FTP at all times and spend the bulk of the ride around 60% of FTP.

​

Make sure to warm up well and cool down afterwards.

prospects.description:

prospects.name: Gran Canaria: Serenity
prospects.description:
Starting at the islands iconic rainbow rocks at Los Azulejos de Veneguera in this session we tackle one of the most stunning climbs on the whole island, known locally as “Serenity”. We’ll be breaking this 10km climb down into three distinct sections, kicking off with a block of 6 x 50 second high tempo efforts with a 10 second burst out of the saddle before taking a swift breather before getting back on it. As we climb through the pine forest we’ll switch things up a touch, alternating between low and high cadence for 30 seconds at a time for around 7 minutes. We’ll then revert back to our 50 second high tempo with 10 second burst out of the saddle efforts before we build up our effort to the summit. This is going to be a challenging workout so make sure you’re ready and whatever you do don’t forget to take a moment to look at the views!!

​

This workout combines multiple different interval types that focus on improving threshold power via over-under style efforts along with low cadence work for your muscular endurance. The first and last climbs also fire up your whole energy systems with some sprints to the summit.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/8735613403)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Half the Road
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2015): _Half The Road_ is a documentary that explores the world of women’s professional cycling, focusing on both the love of sport and the pressing issues of inequality that modern-day female riders face in a male-dominated sport. With footage from some of the world’s best UCI races and interviews with Olympians, World Champions, rookies, coaches, managers, officials, doctors, and family members, _Half The Road_ offers a unique insight into the drive, dedication, and passion it takes for a female cyclist to thrive.

​

Both on and off the bike, the voices and advocates of women’s pro cycling take the audience on a journey of enlightenment, depth, strength, love, humor, and best of all, change & growth.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Sprint/Threshold/Sprint: 2 x 7
prospects.description:
If you want to win races, you've found the right workout! This short session will challenge your anaerobic capacity starting with three repeated efforts, then your sustained power with a steady threshold effort, and then finally your remaining AC and neuromuscular coordination to stay smooth in an all out sprint for the finish line. Easy to see why we like to call it "Race Winners" for short!

​

prospects.name: Igniter
prospects.description:
A highly tuned machine needs its engine warmed up in order to produce the most power as efficiently as possible. Igniter is based on the highly successful warm-up session developed by British Cycling and used by Team Sky as part of their 'marginal gains' program. You'll go through a series of progressive efforts before hitting a couple of high-intensity/high-cadence sprints. You'll emerge ready to CRUSH EVERYTHING BEFORE YOU! This workout is perfect before major events, in conjunction with our Extra Shot workout, or to extend your regular session.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to why warm-ups are so important in this episode of The Knowledge podcast by Wahoo Sports Science:

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)

prospects.name: Cadence Builds/Holds/Single Leg Drills
prospects.description:
This workout combines several technique-driven intervals. These will improve your overall form and efficiency on the bike. The first two drills, Cadence Holds and Builds, are designed to improve the way you recruit your leg, glute, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke. They do this by forcing you to sustain a cadence just above 'comfortable' and by pushing you to your maximal cadence.

​

**Warm-Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: MAP: 2 Sets 5 x 2
prospects.description:
By the end of this session, you will have accumulated 20-minutes at roughly 100% of your MAP. However, that accumulated time is split up over two sets of 5 efforts, each 2-minutes in length. The goal of this session is to accumulate a significant amount of time near VO2max, or the point at which your body is consuming as much oxygen as it possibly can. That means your heart rate and breathing rate will both be near their max by the end of the 4th and 5th interval in each set.

​

Since it takes time for your heart rate and breathing rate to match your effort, for the first part of each interval, you will be taping into your Anaerobic Capacity to produce the required power. Limited recovery ensures that your Anaerobic Capacity is drained before the end of either set, forcing your body to produce as much power as possible aerobically. By splitting these efforts into two sets, you will be producing more power anaerobically compared to doing all ten intervals in a single set. While this means you accumulate less time near your VO2max, you will be able to hold a higher power for the final five intervals. Splitting the efforts will shift the training stress away from your cardiovascular system and onto your muscular system.

Ultimately this session will improve your ability to produce power aerobically in addition to improving your muscular strength and endurance, both of which are key to increasing your MAP and your FTP.

​

**Warm Up**

10 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

7 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

5minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%
